heading: 5.9.1 Exercise 1 Solution
text:
potential solution sl3 Exercise 1 – Predicting Myocardial
Infarction sl3.
code:
library(sl3)
library(origami)
library(data.table)
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

db_data <-
 url("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/benkeser/sllecture/master/chspred.csv")
chspred <- read_csv(file = db_data, col_names = TRUE)

# make task
chspred_task <- make_sl3_Task(
  data = chspred,
  covariates = head(colnames(chspred), -1),
  outcome = "mi"
  )

# make learners
glm_learner <- Lrnr_glm$new()
lasso_learner <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 1)
ridge_learner <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 0)
enet_learner <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 0.5)
# curated_glm_learner uses formula = "mi ~ smoke + beta + waist"
curated_glm_learner <- Lrnr_glm_fast$new(covariates = c("smoke, beta, waist"))
mean_learner <- Lrnr_mean$new() # That is one mean learner!
glm_fast_learner <- Lrnr_glm_fast$new()
ranger_learner <- Lrnr_ranger$new()
svm_learner <- Lrnr_svm$new()
xgb_learner <- Lrnr_xgboost$new()

# screening
screen_cor <- make_learner(Lrnr_screener_corP)
glm_pipeline <- make_learner(Pipeline, screen_cor, glm_learner)

# stack learners together
stack <- make_learner(
  Stack,
  glm_pipeline, glm_learner,
  lasso_learner, ridge_learner, enet_learner,
  curated_glm_learner, mean_learner, glm_fast_learner,
  ranger_learner, svm_learner, xgb_learner
  )

# make and train super learner
sl <- Lrnr_sl$new(
  learners = stack
  )
sl_fit <- sl$train(chspred_task)
sl_fit$print()

CVsl <- CV_lrnr_sl(sl_fit, chspred_task, loss_squared_error)
CVsl

importance <- varimp(sl_fit, loss_squared_error)
importance %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_reorder(X, risk_diff)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = risk_diff, y = name)) +
  geom_dotplot(binaxis = "y") +
  labs(x = "Risk Difference", y = "Covariate", 
       title = "sl3 Variable Importance for Myocardian Infarction Prediction")

heading: 5.9.2 Exercise 2 Solution
text:
potential solution sl3 Exercise 2 – Predicting Recurrent
Ischemic Stroke RCT sl3.
code:
library(sl3)
library(origami)
library(data.table)
library(tidyverse)
library(ROCR) # for AUC calculation
library(ggplot2)

ist_data <- paste0("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tlverse/",
                   "tlverse-handbook/master/data/ist_sample.csv") %>% fread()

# stack
ist_task <- make_sl3_Task(
  data = ist_data,
  outcome = "DRSISC",
  covariates = colnames(ist_data)[-which(names(ist_data) == "DRSISC")],
  drop_missing_outcome = TRUE
  )

# learner library
lrnr_glm <- Lrnr_glm$new()
lrnr_lasso <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 1)
lrnr_ridge <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 0)
lrnr_enet <- Lrnr_glmnet$new(alpha = 0.5)
lrnr_mean <- Lrnr_mean$new() 
lrnr_ranger <- Lrnr_ranger$new()
lrnr_svm <- Lrnr_svm$new()
# xgboost grid
grid_params <- list(max_depth = c(2, 5, 8),
                    eta = c(0.01, 0.15, 0.3))
grid <- expand.grid(grid_params, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE)
params_default <- list(nthread = getOption("sl.cores.learners", 1))
xgb_learners <- apply(grid, MARGIN = 1, function(params_tune) {
  do.call(Lrnr_xgboost$new, c(params_default, as.list(params_tune)))})
learners <- unlist(list(xgb_learners, lrnr_ridge, lrnr_mean, lrnr_lasso,
                        lrnr_glm, lrnr_enet, lrnr_ranger, lrnr_svm),
                   recursive = TRUE)

# super learner
sl <- Lrnr_sl$new(learners)
sl_fit <- sl$train(ist_task)

# AUC
preds <- sl_fit$predict()
obs <- c(na.omit(ist_data$DRSISC))
AUC <- performance(prediction(sl_preds, obs), measure = "auc")@y.values[[1]]
plot(performance(prediction(sl_preds, obs), "tpr", "fpr"))

# CVsl
ist_task_CVsl <- make_sl3_Task(
  data = ist_data,
  outcome = "DRSISC",
  covariates = colnames(ist_data)[-which(names(ist_data) == "DRSISC")],
  drop_missing_outcome = TRUE,
  folds = origami::make_folds(
    n = sum(!is.na(ist_data$DRSISC)), 
    fold_fun = folds_vfold,
    V = 5
    )
  )
CVsl <- CV_lrnr_sl(sl_fit, ist_task_CVsl, loss_loglik_binomial)
CVsl

# sl3 variable importance plot
importance <- varimp(sl_fit, loss_loglik_binomial)

importance %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_reorder(X, risk_diff)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = risk_diff, y = name)) +
  geom_dotplot(binaxis = "y") +
  labs(x = "Risk Difference", y = "Covariate", 
       title = "Variable Importance for Predicting Recurrent Ischemic Stroke")

# Initialize few of the learners:
lrn_xgboost_50 <- Lrnr_xgboost$new(nrounds = 50)
lrn_xgboost_100 <- Lrnr_xgboost$new(nrounds = 100)
lrn_xgboost_500 <- Lrnr_xgboost$new(nrounds = 500)
lrn_mean <- Lrnr_mean$new()
lrn_glm <- Lrnr_glm_fast$new()

## Define the Q learner, which is just a regular learner:
Q_learner <- Lrnr_sl$new(
  learners = list(lrn_xgboost_50, lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_xgboost_500, lrn_mean,
                  lrn_glm),
  metalearner = Lrnr_nnls$new()
)

# Define the g learner, which is a multinomial learner:
#specify the appropriate loss of the multinomial learner:
mn_metalearner <- make_learner(Lrnr_solnp,
                               loss_function = loss_loglik_multinomial,
                               learner_function =
                                 metalearner_linear_multinomial)
g_learner <- make_learner(Lrnr_sl,
                          list(lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_xgboost_500, lrn_mean),
                          mn_metalearner)

# Define the Blip learner, which is a multivariate learner:
learners <- list(lrn_xgboost_50, lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_xgboost_500, lrn_mean,
                 lrn_glm)
b_learner <- create_mv_learners(learners = learners)
# See which learners support multi-class classification:

heading: 7.8.2 Realistic Optimal Individual Regimes
text:
addition considering less complex rules, tmle3mopttx also provides 
option estimate mean realistic, implementable, optimal
individualized treatment. often case assigning particular regime
might ability fully maximize (minimize) desired outcome, 
due global practical positivity constrains, treatment can never 
implemented real life (highly unlikely). , specifying
realistic TRUE, consider possibly suboptimal treatments optimize
outcome question supported data.
code:
# initialize a tmle specification
tmle_spec <- tmle3_mopttx_blip_revere(
  V = c("W4", "W3", "W2", "W1"), type = "blip2",
  learners = learner_list,
  maximize = TRUE, complex = TRUE, realistic = TRUE
)
# fit the TML estimator
fit <- tmle3(tmle_spec, data, node_list, learner_list)

heading: 7.8.3 Q-learning
text:
Alternatively, estimate mean optimal individualized
treatment using Q-learning. optimal rule can learned fitting 
likelihood, consequently estimating optimal rule fit 
likelihood (Sutton, Barto, others 1998, @murphy2003).outline use tmle3mopttx package order estimate mean
ITR using Q-learning. demonstrated previous sections, 
first need initialize specification TMLE parameter 
interest. opposed previous section however, now use
tmle3_mopttx_Q instead tmle3_mopttx_blip_revere order indicate 
want use Q-learning instead TMLE.
code:
# initialize a tmle specification
tmle_spec_Q <- tmle3_mopttx_Q(maximize = TRUE)

# Define data:
tmle_task <- tmle_spec_Q$make_tmle_task(data, node_list)

# Define likelihood:
initial_likelihood <- tmle_spec_Q$make_initial_likelihood(tmle_task,
                                                          learner_list)

heading: 7.9 Variable Importance Analysis with OIT
text:
Suppose one wishes assess importance observed covariate, 
terms maximizing (minimizing) population mean outcome 
optimal individualized treatment regime. particular, covariate 
maximizes (minimizes) population mean outcome optimal
individualized treatment considered covariates optimal
assignment might considered important outcome. put 
context, perhaps optimal allocation treatment 1, denoted \(A_1\), results 
larger mean outcome optimal allocation another treatment (\(A_2\)).
Therefore, label \(A_1\) higher variable importance 
regard maximizing (minimizing) mean outcome optimal
individualized treatment.

heading: 7.9.1 Simulated Data
text:
order run tmle3mopttx variable importance measure, need consider
covariates categorical variables. illustration purpose, bin
baseline covariates corresponding data-generating distribution described
section 5.7.1:Note node list now includes \(W_1\) treatments well! Don’t worry,
still properly adjust baseline covariates.
code:
# bin baseline covariates to 3 categories:
data$W1 <- ifelse(data$W1 < quantile(data$W1)[2], 1,
                  ifelse(data$W1 < quantile(data$W1)[3], 2, 3))

node_list <- list(
  W = c("W3", "W4", "W2"),
  A = c("W1", "A"),
  Y = "Y"
)

heading: 7.9.2 Variable Importance using Targeted Estimation of the value of the ITR
text:
previous sections seen obtain contrast mean
optimal individualized rule mean observed outcome
single covariate- now ready run variable importance analysis
specified covariates. order run variable importance
analysis, first need initialize specification TMLE 
parameter interest done . addition, need specify
data corresponding list nodes, well appropriate
learners outcome regression, propensity score, blip function.
Finally, need specify whether adjust 
covariates assessing variable importance . adjust \(W\)s
analysis, adjust_for_other_A=TRUE, also \(\) covariates
treated exposure variable importance loop.start, initialize specification TMLE parameter 
interest (called tmle3_Spec tlverse nomenclature) simply calling
tmle3_mopttx_vim. First, indicate method used learning optimal
individualized treatment specifying method argument 
tmle3_mopttx_vim. method="Q", using Q-learning rule
estimation, need specify V, type learners arguments
spec, since important Q-learning. However, 
method="SL", corresponds learning optimal individualized
treatment using outlined methodology, need specify type
pseudo-blip use estimation problem, whether want 
maximize minimize outcome, complex realistic rules. Finally, 
method="SL" also need communicate ’re interested learning 
rule dependent V covariates specifying V argument. 
method="Q" method="SL", need indicate whether want maximize
minimize mean optimal individualized rule. Finally, also
need specify whether final comparison mean optimal
individualized rule mean observed outcome 
multiplicative scale (risk ratio) linear (similar average treatment
effect).final result tmle3_vim tmle3mopttx spec ordered list
mean outcomes optimal individualized treatment categorical
covariates dataset.
code:
# initialize a tmle specification
tmle_spec <- tmle3_mopttx_vim(
  V=c("W2"),
  type = "blip2",
  learners = learner_list,
  contrast = "multiplicative",
  maximize = FALSE,
  method = "SL",
  complex = TRUE,
  realistic = FALSE
)
# fit the TML estimator
vim_results <- tmle3_vim(tmle_spec, data, node_list, learner_list,
  adjust_for_other_A = TRUE
)

heading: 7.10 Real World Data and tmle3mopttx
text:
Finally, cement everything learned far real data application.
previous sections, using WASH Benefits data,
corresponding Effect water quality, sanitation, hand washing, 
nutritional interventions child development rural Bangladesh trial.
main aim cluster-randomized controlled trial assess 
impact six intervention groups, including:chlorinated drinking waterchlorinated drinking waterimproved sanitationimproved sanitationhandwashing soaphandwashing soapcombined water, sanitation, handwashingcombined water, sanitation, handwashingimproved nutrition counselling provision lipid-based nutrient
supplementsimproved nutrition counselling provision lipid-based nutrient
supplementscombined water, sanitation, handwashing, nutrition.combined water, sanitation, handwashing, nutrition.aim estimate optimal ITR corresponding value optimal
ITR main intervention WASH Benefits data.start, let’s load data, convert columns class numeric,
take quick look :, specify NPSEM via node_list object. outcome 
interest weight--height Z-score seek maximize, whereas 
treatment six intervention groups aimed improving living conditions.
collected baseline covariates correspond \(W\).pick potential effect modifiers, including mother’s education, current
living conditions (floor), possession material items including 
refrigerator. concentrate covariates might indicative 
socio-economic status individuals involved trial.
code:
washb_data <- fread("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tlverse/tlverse-data/master/wash-benefits/washb_data.csv",
                    stringsAsFactors = TRUE)
washb_data <- washb_data[!is.na(momage), lapply(.SD, as.numeric)]
head(washb_data, 3)
#>      whz tr fracode month aged sex momage momedu momheight hfiacat Nlt18 Ncomp
#> 1:  0.00  1       4     9  268   2     30      2    146.40       1     3    11
#> 2: -1.16  1       4     9  286   2     25      2    148.75       3     2     4
#> 3: -1.05  1      20     9  264   2     25      2    152.15       1     1    10
#>    watmin elec floor walls roof asset_wardrobe asset_table asset_chair
#> 1:      0    1     0     1    1              0           1           1
#> 2:      0    1     0     1    1              0           1           0
#> 3:      0    0     0     1    1              0           0           1
#>    asset_khat asset_chouki asset_tv asset_refrig asset_bike asset_moto
#> 1:          1            0        1            0          0          0
#> 2:          1            1        0            0          0          0
#> 3:          0            1        0            0          0          0
#>    asset_sewmach asset_mobile
#> 1:             0            1
#> 2:             0            1
#> 3:             0            1
node_list <- list(W = names(washb_data)[!(names(washb_data) %in%
                                          c("whz", "tr"))],
                  A = "tr", Y = "whz")
table(washb_data$momedu)
#> 
#>    1    2    3 
#>  733 1441 2503
table(washb_data$floor)
#> 
#>    0    1 
#> 4177  500
table(washb_data$asset_refrig)
#> 
#>    0    1 
#> 4305  372
summary(washb_data$whz)
#>    Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
#> -4.6700 -1.2800 -0.6000 -0.5859  0.0800  4.9700
# Initialize few of the learners:
lrn_xgboost_50 <- Lrnr_xgboost$new(nrounds = 50)
lrn_xgboost_100 <- Lrnr_xgboost$new(nrounds = 100)
lrn_mean <- Lrnr_mean$new()

## Define the Q learner, which is just a regular learner:
Q_learner <- Lrnr_sl$new(
  learners = list(lrn_xgboost_50, lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_mean),
  metalearner = Lrnr_nnls$new()
)

# Define the g learner, which is a multinomial learner:
#specify the appropriate loss of the multinomial learner:
mn_metalearner <- make_learner(Lrnr_solnp,
                               loss_function = loss_loglik_multinomial,
                               learner_function =
                                 metalearner_linear_multinomial)
g_learner <- make_learner(Lrnr_sl,
                          list(lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_mean),
                          mn_metalearner)

# Define the Blip learner, which is a multivariate learner:
learners <- list(lrn_xgboost_50, lrn_xgboost_100, lrn_mean)
b_learner <- create_mv_learners(learners = learners)

learner_list <- list(Y = Q_learner, A = g_learner, B = b_learner)
# initialize a tmle specification
tmle_spec <- tmle3_mopttx_blip_revere(
  V = c("momedu", "floor", "asset_refrig"), type = "blip2",
  learners = learner_list, maximize = TRUE, complex = TRUE,
  realistic = FALSE
)

# fit the TML estimator
fit <- tmle3(tmle_spec, data=washb_data, node_list, learner_list)
#> Warning in process_data(data, nodes, column_names = column_names, flag = flag, :
#> Missing covariate data detected: imputing covariates.
